text:
Ask yourself, “How many times have I been stoked to talk to a bot rather than a human?” I don’t care if it’s a chatbot or a phone system. I can't think of a single time that I’d rather talk to a bot. If I wanted a bot to answer things for me I’d use Google or the site’s search box if they one.

The key problem here is that companies do this because it’s easier for them but don’t consider whether or not it makes things easier for their customers.

Can they? Maybe. Do they most of the time? No. 

If companies would take the time to carefully configure them to make sure they quickly and efficiently routed people to the right human, then it’d be great. But most companies don’t do this.

Chatbots, by and large improve company experience, not user experience.

Especially when they are available 24/7 but then a human isn't available 24/7. That’d be like going through a long touchstone dial sequence on the phone only to get hung up on by an automated system because it couldn't handle the request. :face_with_symbols_on_mouth:
